characters: TWO YEARS AND ONE MINUTE EARLIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CIGARETTE - slowly burns in an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: It's not that we'll mistake them for the truth. The real danger is that if we hear enough lies, then we no longer recognize the truth at all. What can we do then? What else is left but to abandon even the hope of truth, and content ourselves instead... with stories. The apartment is cramped. Bookshelves. Stacks of scientif journals. Soviet-era furniture. Nicotine wallpaper.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: In these stories, it doesn't matter who the heroes are. All we want to know is: who is to blame? Well. In this story, it was Anatoly Dyatlov. And he was the best choice. An arrogant, unpleasant man, he ran the room that night, he gave the orders... and no friends. Or at least not important ones. A CAT pads softly over a TYPEWRITER on a wooden desk. Through an open archway, we see a MAN sitting at a kitche table. Takes the cigarette from the ashtray. Smokes.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: And now Dyatlov will spend the next ten years in a prison labour camp. IN THE KITCHEN - the soft tick-tick-tick of a small CLOCK on the kitchen table. It's a little past 1:00 AM.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Next to the clock: a cup of tea, the ashtray, and a chunk Soviet-era AUDIO CASSETTE RECORDER. Tape playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course that sentence is doubly unfair. There were far greater criminals than him at work. The listening man is: VALERY LEGASOV, 52. Glasses. Pale skin, a bit papery. His hair is thinning in odd patches.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: And as for what Dyatlov did do, the man doesn't deserve prison. Legasov takes a drag on his cigarette. Listening calmly t his own voice playing back through the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: He deserves death. Legasov presses STOP on the recorder. Picks up a small microphone wired to the cassette player. Hits PLAY/RECORD

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: But instead, ten years for "criminal mismanagement". What does that mean? No one knows and it doesn't matter. What does matter is that to them, justice was done. Because you see? A just world is a sane world. (beat) There is nothing sane about Chernobyl. What happened there, what happened after... even the good we did... all of it... all of it... (beat) Madness. He removes his glasses. Rubs his eyes. Exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I've given you everything I know. They'll try to deny it, the way they always do. Will you prevail? I do not know. I only know you'll do your best to try. Legasov presses STOP. Then REWIND. As the tape spins, we see: FIVE OTHER TAPES on the table, each numbered. Legasov crosses to a WINDOW. Moves the curtain slightly t the side and peeks down at: HIS POV - a CAR parked across the street. The interior LIGHT is on. It's always on. Someone's always there.  103 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moscow is dead quiet. Legasov carefully steps outside, remaing in shadow, holding his COAT closed with his hands There's a slight bulge. Across the street - THE PARKED CA A MAN sits in the car. Dome light on. He's pouring coffee from a thermos into a cup, and while he's distracted, Legasov quickly PASSES through the BEAM of a streetlamp t A DARK ALLEY next to his building. Back in shadows. He moves past the rubbish bins and into a small garden area. Then removes the PACKAGE from inside his coat, and stashe it in a small air vent, well out of view. Now, only one final task remains. He checks his watch. 1:19. Nearly time. He removes a single cigarette from a nearly full pack. Tosses the rest of the pack away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat is now on the kitchen table. It raises its head a the sound of the door opening and closing. Legasov enters. Removes his jacket. Moves quickly to the window and checks once again. HIS POV: the car light is still on. But no one's gotten out. He was unseen. Legasov lights his one cigarette. A long draw. Checks his watch again. Another draw. He's rushing now. He places four small bowls on the floor in a row. Fills each with scraps of boiled chicken from a plate. Walks back to the table. Another drag of the cigarette. Looks at the clock. It's now 1:23. Okay. Rests the cigarette back in the ashtray. Walks out of frame. We stay with the CAT and the CLOCK. We HEAR: a closet doo opening... something jangles. The second hand ticks. It's 1:23 and 20 seconds. SOUND: footsteps 1:23 and 30 seconds. SOUND: a chair is moved 1:23 and 40 seconds  105 106 ...now silence as the cat lowers its head, bored. Tick ti tick tick. 1:23:41, 42, 43, 44 -- SOUND: a chair toppling and a sharp SNAP. The cat lifts its head. Startled. REVERSE TO REVEAL - Legasov's legs, hanging in mid-air, slightly turning, out of focus in the background. The cigarette still burns. Smoke curls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW THROUGH GLASS - a small city of 50,000 people, mostl living in large block apartment buildings. Beyond that, LIGHTS clustered in the distance, perhaps tw or three miles away. Some white, some red, some blinking. The Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant.

dialogues.speaker: TWO YEARS AND ONE MINUTE EARLIER
dialogues.text: We PULL BACK to see we're:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out at the blinking lights of the nearby power plant through a WINDOW. This apartment is simple. Sparse. Flat, powder blue walls. Tiny kitchenette. ON THE WALL - a PHOTO of a young man holding a woman off the ground. She's laughing. Scared. In love. Next to the photo, a calendar. The year is 1986. We hear: a woman RETCHING off-screen. A toilet flushing. LYUDMILLA IGNATENKO, 23, emerges from the bathroom. Catching her breath. Sick. But happy. Something beautiful She peers in to her bedroom, where her husband VASILY, 25 sleeps soundly. Good. She'll tell him later. Oh. Her cigarette in the ashtray. No more smoking. She quickly stubs it out. A growing HISS. Lyudmilla crosses o of frame. We hear tea being poured.  107 THROUGH THE WINDOW - we see but do not hear a small EXPLOSION at the power plant, followed almost instantly b a MASSIVE EXPLOSION that turns night into day. And still, no sound. A mute apocalypse. One second goes by. Lyudmilla re-enters frame. Oblivious. Two seconds. She sits down. Three seconds - SHOCKWAVE - like a massive fist SLAMMING into the side of the building... and she jolts back. The BEDROOM DOOR flings open, and Vasily emerges. Sleeveless undershirt, pyjama bottoms. Confused. The nois He joins Lyudmilla at the window. Sees... FIRES ringing a terrible crimson-red GLOW at the power plant, as if the building has opened a gate to hell. And rising out of the inferno-- an unnatural, glowing, BRIGHT BLUE COLUMN OF LIGHT, like a beacon shooting straight up into the sky... seemingly to the stars. Dogs begin barking. Apartment lights turn on. Pripyat awakens. It's 1:24 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sound except distant hissing noises. All we see is SWIRLING WHITE DUST, illuminated by emergen BACKUP LIGHTS. And now we make out: MEN - the control room operators, dressed identically in white uniforms. White paper hats covering their heads. Al in the same position. Cowering. Except for one man, who stands. 55 years old, gray mustache, white hair swept back on his head. This is ANATOLY DYATLOV. CLOSE ON DYATLOV - SLOW MOTION - the white dust swirls eerily around his face. He's bewildered. Shell-shocked. We hear a voice echoing as if from far away:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Comrade Dyatlov? Comrade Dyatlov? Time SNAPS BACK into rhythm, and Dyatlov registers:  ALEXANDR AKIMOV, 33, black mustache, glasses. Staring at him - saying his name.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Comrade Dyatlov?

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: I don't know. BRAZHNIK, 20's, enters the control room in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: BRAZHNIK
dialogues.text: There's a fire in the turbine hall. Something blew up... Dyatlov pauses. Lost in thought? His face is unreadable. Agonizing seconds tick by. Then he turns coldly to Akimov

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: The turbine hall. The control system tank. Hydrogen. You and Toptunov-- you morons blew the tank. LEONID TOPTUNOV, 25, blond, thin, terrified. His boyish moustache is a struggling, wispy version of Akimov's.

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: No, that's not-- Akimov signals Toptunov not to argue.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (to the room) This is an emergency. Everyone stay calm. Our first priority is-- PEREVOZCHENKO, 30's, bursts in. Panting. Frantic.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: It exploded.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: We know. Akimov-- are we cooling the reactor core?

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: We shut it down. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AKIMOV (cont'd) (checks the panel) But the control rods are still-- they're not all the way in-- I disengaged the clutch. I don't-- Perevozchenko watches Akimov and Dyatlov talking about th reactor.. are they out of their minds?

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll disconnect the servos from the standby console. You two! ACROSS THE ROOM: BORIS STOLYARCHUK and IGOR KIRSCHENBAUM, late 20's, sit together at a control panel. Shell-shocked

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Get the backup pumps running. We need water moving through the core. That's all that matters. As Dyatlov heads for the door--

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: There is no core. Dyatlov stops. Turns. Everyone in the room stares. Two TRAINEES, PROSKURYAKOV and KUDRYAVTSEV, both 30, look at each other. For the first time, real fear.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: It exploded. The core exploded. A beat, then Dyatlov shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: He's in shock. Get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: The lid is off. The stack is burning. I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (calmly) You're confused. RBMK reactor cores don't explode. Akimov... Akimov hesitates. Stares at the control panel. A plastic cover is lifted up over a large black switch labeled AZ-5 Then he looks at young, frightened Toptunov.  108

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Leonid. We did everything right. Something-- something strange has happened. Toptunov grabs Akimov's arm. Whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: Do you taste metal?

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Akimov. Akimov tastes the metal in his mouth. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Comrade Perevozschenko, what you're saying is physically impossible. A core can't explode. It has to be the tank. Perevozchenko looks at Akimov in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: We're wasting time. LET'S GO. Get the hydrogen out of the generators, and pump water into the core. As Dyatlov turns to exit--

dialogues.speaker: BRAZHNIK
dialogues.text: What about the fire? Dyatlov looks back at him. Annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Call the fire brigade. Dyaltov EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Battery-powered emergency lights shine into swirls of dus We hear a distant ALARM blaring. Someone's shouting. DYATLOV - strides with purpose. No emotion. Stone cold. Then stops. Feels the COLD AIR on his face. Turns to: A SMALL LANDING with a WINDOW. The glass has been BLOWN I and shards litter the floor. Dyatlov walks slowly across the broken glass to the window...  109 110 He walks up to the open window. Looks at the grounds belo Chunks of DEBRIS litter the ground. Hard to tell in the moonlight just what it is. But some of it is BURNING. Dyatlov stares at the debris for a moment. Then calmly turns and continues down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BURNING RUBBLE - thick black chunks of GRAPHITE, with smooth channels carved through them. We lift up from the rubble... and now we see: REACTOR BUILDING #4 - and the massive GAPING HOLE in its side - tons of steel and graphite and plaster and cinderblock vomited out from the blast... FIRES burn in scattered pockets where red-hot graphite ha ignited the tar-covered roof. Pouring out from somewhere inside the building, BLACK SMOKE. And still, the awful scarlet glow. And still, the impossible BEACON of BLUE LIGHT spiring up... We hear: crackling static - and a strange, repeating audi tone.

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK 110
dialogues.text: The tone stops as a new audio signal is connected. Then - voices over a phone or perhaps a radio, speaking Russian. This is a recording of the actual call made that night. Translation only is SUBTITLED over black:

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT EMERGENCY DISPATCH
dialogues.text: Hello, is this Military Fire Station

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY FIRE STATION 2
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT EMERGENCY DISPATCH
dialogues.text: What's happening with the accident?  10.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY FIRE STATION 2
dialogues.text: Explosion in the main building between third and fourth blocks.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT EMERGENCY DISPATCH
dialogues.text: Are there people there?

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY FIRE STATION 2
dialogues.text: Yes. (We hear another voice on the military fire station end)

dialogues.speaker: OTHER VOICE
dialogues.text: Wake up the bosses. Call them.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY FIRE STATION 2
dialogues.text: I already called mine.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER VOICE
dialogues.text: Wake them up, wake them all up. Wake up the entire officer's block. AUDIO TONE - then a new call

dialogues.speaker: FIRE DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Fire Department.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT EMERGENCY DISPATCH
dialogues.text: Hello, Ivankov?

dialogues.speaker: FIRE DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT FIRE DISPATCH
dialogues.text: You've been called to Pripyat. Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FIRE DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes I can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT FIRE DISPATCH
dialogues.text: At the nuclear plant over there, in the third and fourth blocks. The roof is on fire. AUDIO TONE - call ends The black is WIPED OPEN into light, and we're:  111 112 113 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --in a CLOSET, looking out at VASILY, in a t-shirt and uniform pants. He grabs his boots. Lyudmilla watches him nervously.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: You're not on call tonight. He hustles to get his boots on.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: They're bringing everyone in. Military and civil. Pripyat, Polesskoe. Even Kiev. It's a big one.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: It doesn't look right. The color.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Pravik thinks they're shining floodlights or something.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: But are there chemicals? He pulls on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Chemicals? No, the problem's the roof. It's covered in tar. It's going to burn all night and stink like hell. But that's the worst of it. She opens her mouth to say something, but he takes her fa in his hands. Gives her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: Go to sleep. It'll be over before you wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark hallway. Smoke. Sparks shower down from severed electric lines arcing into flooding water. Steam hissing. PEREVOZCHENKO lurches into view. We LEAD him through the twisted, mangled maze. A disaster area of debris, collapsed ceilings, spurting steam... But he pushes through until he gets to an OPEN DOOR - and we follow him in to: DOSIMETRY - NIKOLAI GORBACHENKO is cowering under his des SPARKS exploding down from a hole in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Is it war? Perevozchenko searches frantically through the debris.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: Where's the dosimeter?

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Here... here... Gorbachenko crawls out and hands Perevozchenko a brown leather case with the DOSIMETER. We hear something heavy COLLAPSING above them. Gorbachenko flinches.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Are they bombing? Perevozchenko doesn't answer. Just stares at the dosimete in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this? 3.6 roentgen?

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: That's as high as it goes. The good one's locked in a safe. I don't have the key-- (sees) Valera-- your face... Perevozchenko's face has DARKENED. A reddish brown TAN. H doesn't know. Doesn't care. He throws the useless dosimeter aside and grabs Gorbachenko, lifting him to his feet.  13.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: I'm going to find Khodemchuk. You get Shashenok. He's in 604. Go. Go! Perevozchenko wanders DOWN A TUNNEL away from us and we swing around to Gorbachenko, who is terrified. Now WE FOLLOW GORBACHENKO as he heads up a steep staircas into DARKNESS - coming around on him so we're leading him watching his face as it's illuminated by sparks and the orange flicker of SPOT FIRES... A MAN LURCHES OUT OF THE DARKNESS into Gorbachenko and VOMITS BLOOD in a violent ejection, spattering Gorbachenko's white uniform with red.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Shit! The man stumbles away from us, and we WHIP around to PROSKURYAKOV and KUDRYAVTSEV, the trainees, running down the stairs at us.

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: We need to get to the reactor hall. The lift's destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: (points) Across to the stairs. That way. The trainees run off in that direction. Gorbachenko yells after them...

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Why are you going there? No answer. They're gone. Then he sees: a METAL DOOR ahead The number 604 stencilled in the concrete beside it. We follow him in to the DEVASTATED ROOM - debris everywhere, and in a puddle of water, under a fallen BEAM Oh god. SHASHENOK - pinned. Bloody foam bubbling from his mouth. But breathing. A FIGURE STUMBLES BY in the doorway. Gorbachenko sees.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: A BUILDING 4 WORKER STUMBLES BACK - trickle of blood down the side of his face. DUST in his hair.  14.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Help me. The Building 4 Worker joins Gorbachenko. They ROLL the be off Shashenok, then PULL HIM UP by his arms... They support him from under each armpit, his arms around their necks. Gorbachenko presses Shashenok's RIGHT HAND tight to his chest to keep him steady, and as they MOVE: --we LEAVE THEM and DROP DOWN through a HOLE in the floor past a cross-section of torn up plumbing and wires, and arrive one floor below in the complex to find: PEREVOZCHENKO - his face even DARKER now - skin beginning to swell - wading through more floodwater and debris, including CHUNKS of BLACK MATERIAL... From somewhere, the steady sound of BANG, BANG, BANG - metal on metal... Perevozchenko climbs upstairs out of the water and: BANG - a bent metal DOOR pops open, and a new face - YUVCHENKO, emerges holding a fire extinguisher.

dialogues.speaker: PEREVOZCHENKO
dialogues.text: Have you seen Khodemchuk?

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: No-- where's Viktor? Perevozchenko starts to shake his head "I don't know" -вЂ then vomit cascades out from his mouth, his nose. Yuvchen backs away in fright, drops the extinguisher and-- --now WE FOLLOW YUVCHENKO, 25 years-old, 6'5", powerful a athletic, as he RUNS deeper into the complex, jumping ove LIVE WIRES and debris, as fast as he can... until he sees

dialogues.speaker: VIKTOR
dialogues.text: --a body next to a large PUMP. Yuvchenko runs over to: VIKTOR DEGTYARENKO, 31 - burned and covered in blood... w can barely make out a face at all beyond the whites of hi eyes. He's trembling. Seizing.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: Can you stand?  115 116 15.

dialogues.speaker: VIKTOR
dialogues.text: Kh-- dem-ch-- Khdem-- Viktor stops trying to make his mouth work. His eyes roll to the left - toward a BLASTED OPEN WALL. Yuvchenko stands up, and we FOLLOW as he walks slowly through the opening into: THE PUMP ROOM - in ruins. Massive chunks of concrete embedded in the enormous machinery. From underneath one massive column, a steady trickle of blood. We can't see Khodemchuk under there. But we know he's dead. One section of wall - three foot thick concrete and rebar rocks back and forth as if it were rubber. We follow Yuvchenko's eyes to: A PUDDLE OF WATER on the ground, coming from a broken pipe. In the reflection of the shimmering water - strange WHITE DOTS... We come up and around on Yuvchenko and look down on him a he lifts his head - stunned beyond words-- And we TURN to see what he sees. An enormous, impossible hole in the ceiling of the building. And the stars shining down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON - DYATLOV - walking back toward Control Room 4. His face as stoic as ever. Granite jaw. Unblinking eyes. He stops at the sound of SIRENS approaching from outside. a lot of them... and growing louder... Then he resumes walking. No change in expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Akimov is at the panel. Toptunov is dialing a phone.

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: No answer. The internal lines are down.  16.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Keep trying. Try all of them. Dyatlov enters.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK,
dialogues.text: Doesn't want

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: I dropped the control rods from the other panel.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: They're still up.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: They're only a third in, I don't know why-- I already sent the trainees to the reactor hall to lower them by hand.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (frustrated) What about the pumps?

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: I can't get through to Khodemchuk. The phones are down.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Fuck the phones and fuck Khodemchuk. Are the pumps on or not?

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Stolyarchuk? looks up like a deer in the headlights. Dyatlov's eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: My panel's not working. I tried calling for the electricians but--

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit about the panel! I need water in my reactor core. Get down there and make sure those pumps are on. Stolyarchuk looks at Akimov, but Akimov won't look back. one will challenge this. Kirschenbaum wants to say something, but the words stick in his throat.  117 17.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Now. Cowed, Stolyarchuk scurries out of the control room. Dyatlov turns back to Akimov.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: What does the dosimeter say?

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: 3.6 roentgen. But that's as high as the meter-- Dyatlov waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: 3.6 -- not great, not terrible. Toptunov looks at Akimov. Scared. And once again, Akimov comforts him... his mantra...

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: We did everything right.

dialogues.speaker: SIRENS BLARE.
dialogues.text: POV through the windshield of a fire engine as it approaches the reactor building. A few fire engines are already there, lights flashing. Firefighters are rushing... connecting fire engines to th power plant water supply... We follow VASILY out of the truck. He and his fellow firefighters are dressed the same. Boots and jackets and helmets... but no gloves. And underneath the jackets... white t-shirts. He looks at the building. From here, he can see the spot fires up on the roof. But there's a MASSIVE plume of smok billowing up from somewhere inside the building. And fainter now, but still there, the trace of that impossible blue light... Now that he's close to it, Vasily realizes this is much bigger, and much worse, than it seemed from afar.

dialogues.speaker: MISHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vasily...  118 18. Vasily looks over at MISHA, 23, another firefighter. Mish is standing next to a pile of the BLACK RUBBLE. There are strange SMOOTH GROOVES running through it. It almost look like bits of SCULPTURE.

dialogues.speaker: MISHA
dialogues.text: What is this? Misha picks up a piece of the rubble with his bare hand.

dialogues.speaker: MISHA
dialogues.text: It's warm.

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Don't fuck around with it. Let's just get these hooked up. Misha tosses the rubble aside. Vasily begins pulling connection hoses from the side of t engine. As he pulls, the smoke wafts by him, and he SPITS

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: You taste metal?

dialogues.speaker: MISHA
dialogues.text: Yeah. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: VASILY
dialogues.text: (worried) I don't know. The valves, Misha! Let's go! As Vasily pulls the hoses, MISHA starts opening a water supply valve with a wrench. Misha takes his hand off the wrench-- the hand he held th warm rubble with-- and SHAKES it in the air. It hurts. It hurts more than it should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorbachenko and the Building 4 Worker emerge from smoke, stumbling ahead as best they can, still carrying SHASHENO around their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHENKO
dialogues.text: Someone!  119 19. Another PLANT WORKER heads over to sub in for Gorbachenko Relieved of his burden, Gorbachenko immediately falls to his hands and knees and begins VOMITING. As he wretches, he winces in pain... his right hand hurts And his chest. He pulls his uniform shirt open to reveal: ON GORBACHENKO'S CHEST, there's a strip of FAINT RED, and then below in BRIGHT RED, a round shape and four smaller RED OVALS. An arm. A palm. Fingertips. A BURN MARK in the shape of Shashenok's HAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROSKURYAKOV and KUDRYAVTSEV enter a long corridor. As th move down the seemingly endless hallway, they see: A FIGURE in the distance, moving slowly toward them, carrying something large over his shoulder. They walk toward each other, meeting in the middle of thi strange purgatory, and now Proskuryakov and Kudryavtsev s the figure is YUVCHENKO. And he has a limp, bloody VIKTOR slung over his shoulder. Oh god. They stare, unsure of wh to say. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: What do you need? Oh. Right.

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: We have to get into the reactor hall to lower the control rods. But the door is jammed in.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: I don't think there are control rods. I don't think there's a core.

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: No, you're mistaken. Akimov said. Yuvchenko considers. Then lowers Viktor to the ground. Rests him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: Does he need a doctor?  120 121 20.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuvchenko leads the two trainees down a dark, SPARKING hall. They're SWEATING. Tremendous heat up here. Smoke. They're close to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: Up there. Ahead: a LARGE METAL DOOR, covered in DUST, bent slightly toward them, as if punched by a huge fist. Yuvchenko turns to the trainees.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: Akimov-- Yuvchenko puts his hand up. Doesn't matter. If they're right, they need to go in. And if they're wrong...

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: I'll hold it open. Move quickly. They nod. Yuvchenko tests the door. It barely gives. Yuvchenko presses the side of his body against the door, plants his powerful legs, and with a grunt: PUSHES the door open - just wide enough for the trainees pass through. The door's weight is pushing back... Yuvchenko's brute strength is the only thing keeping it propped open.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: Go go go-- The trainees SQUEEZE through into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trainees enter the UPPER LEVEL of the hall, ona catwalk high above the reactor pit.  122 21. They stare in utter shock at: THE UPPER BIOLOGICAL SHIELD - a massive 1,000 ton, 45 foo diameter STEEL circle. It's the cover of the reactor core. Except it's not covering the core anymore. It's been blown nearly UPRIGHT like the lifted-up top of a soup can. And spidering out from its exposed underside, hundreds of TWISTED FUEL CHANNELS, like bristles on the end of a brus And underneath that, like a bomb crater in the floor: THE OPEN REACTOR PIT - burning graphite, torn fuel rods. Their minds cannot comprehend. They are staring into a wide-open nuclear reactor. One of them finally gasps in a breath. Already feeling a wave of nausea. He looks at the other trainee. The man's face is dark brown. An instant nuclear tan. And the way the other trainee is staring back at him, he knows he looks the same. They STUMBLE BACKWARD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuvchenko grits his teeth... digging in... and then: THE TRAINEES run back out of the room. They don't stop. They just run. Yuvchenko lets the door finally CLOSE. Shouts after them.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: Hey! No answer. And then: pain. Intense, searing pain. He lifts his uniform shirt. His shoulder... bright red. He lowers the waist of his trousers. His hip, BURNED to t flesh below the skin. The movement of the cloth against i nearly makes him pass out... He looks back at the door.  123 22. IN THE DUST - the pattern of where his body had been pressed against the door. Shoulder. Hip. Lower leg. He backs away in horror, then HOBBLES off, his burnt leg barely working... shouting into the dark after the trainees-- as if they could help him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night is lit up by the flashing lights of emergency vehicles. Dozens of firefighters are already at work getting water on the fire they can see. FROM O.S. - a man SCREAMS in agony. Vasily stops and turn to see: MISHA - on the ground, screaming, held in place by their commanding officer, PRAVIK, 24. A MEDIC has begun to slowly REMOVE the GLOVE from Misha's hand. With every inch, Misha howls in pain. Pravik sees Vasily.

dialogues.speaker: PRAVIK
dialogues.text: Ignatenko! Get on his hose! Vasily runs a few feet to the pump truck Misha was stationed on. He picks the hose up from the ground. He's joined by a truck pump operator, TITENOK, 24-- --who quickly opens the valves on the truck. Vasily begin spraying a BLAST of water into a burning pile of rubble. ANOTHER SCREAM, as the medic finally pulls the GLOVE OFF Misha, and now Vasily sees: Misha's HAND is burnt beyond recognition. Strips of skin hanging off of it. Pravik and the medic stare at it, stunned. Vasily sees the BLACK RUBBLE Misha held. Just feet away from him. He takes one step back from it.  124 23. And keeps spraying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyudmilla stands outside along with other people from the building, looking up at the sky, which reflects the unsee fire with an eerie glow. No one seems nervous. No one except her.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lyudmilla! OKSANA, 30, walks with a CROWD of people from the buildin next door. Men, women, children... about fifteen of them. Some of the women carry infants. Some, like Oksana, push BABY PRAMS.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: You want to come with us?

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: Come where?

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: We're going to the railroad bridge to get a better look. It's not like anyone can sleep with all the sirens.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: I don't think you should. It could be dangerous. Oksana's husband, MIKHAIL, scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: What do you mean dangerous? It's a fire. It's over there, we're over here. Oksana gives Mikhail an angry whack on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: What? (realizes) Oh. Oksana crosses to Lyudmilla. Puts a comforting hand on he  125 24.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: Is Vasily-- ? Lyudmilla nods.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: Did he say it was bad?

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: No. He said it was just the roof. There. You see?

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: He's never gotten hurt before. None of the boys have. Yes? He'll be fine. Get some rest. Oskana gives her a hug, and then rejoins the rest of the group on their way to the railroad bridge. Small children skip along, laughing, excited to be out in the middle of the night. Lyudmilla looks out at the distant glow. She couldn't say why or how she knows. She just does. Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Dyatlov. Standing with his back against the wal Palms together in front of his mouth. Tapping his fingers Thinking. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: The tank. It's big enough. Akimov and Toptunov turn to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: This kind of explosion. The control tank on 71, it's 100 cubic meters.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (see?) 110. It could do this. Definitely.  25. He's nodding to himself. As if someone else is convincing him of this fact. Then: The door OPENS. And before we can see what they see, Toptunov covers his mouth with his hand. Jesus... It's PROSKURYAKOV. His face is now DARK BROWN. Eyes nearl swollen shut.

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: It's gone. I looked right into it. I looked into the core. Akimov stares in shock at Dyatlov. Panic rising inside hi But Dyatlov doesn't even flinch.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Did you lower the control rods or not? Proskuryakov turns to him in confusion. Then begins RETCHING.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Take him to the infirmary. (beat) Toptunov! Take him! Toptunov rushes over to the trainee, and as he helps him out of the room--

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: Where's Kudryavtsev?

dialogues.speaker: PROSKURYAKOV
dialogues.text: He fell... Toptunov exits with Proskuryakov, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I need a medic! Anyone?! Dyatlov resumes leaning against the wall. Fingers back in front of his mouth. Then he feels Akimov's eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: He's delusional.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: His face.  Akimov looks 26.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (waves it off) Ruptured condenser lines. The feedwater is mildly contaminated. He'll be fine. I've seen worse. down. That can't be true. But the alternative is unthinkable. Akimov looks Oh god. Akimov still

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Do we still have a phone line to the outside? (beat) Akimov? back up. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Call in the day shift.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: But... if--

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: We have to keep water flowing through the core. We need electricians, mechanics-- we need bodies. How many times do I have to say it? hesitates. Dyatlov deliberately walks toward Akimov. Unblinking. Col

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: I'm going to the Administration Building now. To call Bryukhanov. And Fomin. They're going to want a full report. I don't know if I can make things better for you. But I can certainly make them worse. He stops just inches from Akimov's face.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Call in the day shift, Comrade Akimov. Akimov swallows. Then:  126 127 27.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Yes. Comrade Dyatlov. Dyatlov stares into Akimov's eyes a beat too long. Then nods, satisfied... and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near silence. Barely crickets. We're in front of PRIPYAT HOSPITAL - five interconnected buildings, each six storey tall. The buildings are oddly generic. Soviet cookie-cutters, made of concrete and institutional white tiling. There are large letters on the roof. We'll translate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off-screen, we hear a woman is GROANING and STRAINING in pain. But we're looking at: SVETLANA ZINCHENKO, 25, wearing a doctor's jacket. She's staring out the window at the distant fire.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're doing fine. Raise her up. A little more. Behind her: THE LABOUR WARD. A large, open space. Bare walls - white tile halfway up, sickly mint-green the rest Electrical lines are routed up the surface of the walls. The floor is brown tile, with drains set in every ten fee There are a SIX delivery gurneys... simple steel frame co with thin mattress pads and crude gynecological stirrups. Bright fluorescents beat down on: TWO WOMEN on the cots, each in labour. Hairnets on, hospital gown covering their tops, nude from the waist down, in stirrups. Nurses attend to them, along with AN OLD DOCTOR, likely i his 70's. It may be 1986, but in here, it seems more like 1886. A nurse HAND-CRANKS a cot to help raise a woman's head.  28.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Good. There. Okay. He points to the patients as he instructs the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: This one, maybe an hour. The other two, not until morning. He talks a bit too loudly. Hard of hearing.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: And how is it downstairs, Doctor Zinchenko?

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: Quiet. He removes his gloves. Throughout their conversation, one of the women in labour continues to GROAN in pain.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Always is. Nothing at this hour but babies. You know I once went two days without sleep? Ten women went into labour at the same time-- did I ever tell you this story? Zinchenko's still staring out the window. Distracted.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: Yes. The old doctor is a bit hurt by that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, I won't need you in here for a while. If you want, get some rest in the break room. He opens one of the patient's charts. Begins making handwritten notations. Zinchenko finally turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: They haven't brought anyone in from the fire.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What fire?

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: The power plant.  29.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Oh? Then it must not be too bad.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: Do we stock iodine? He didn't hear that over the woman's groaning.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: (louder) Iodine. He looks up from his chart.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You mean disinfectant?

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: No. Pills. Does the hospital stock iodine pills?

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Iodine pills... (confused) Why would we have iodine pills? Off her face, we hear the shrill RING of:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --a bedside TELEPHONE. One ring. Two. Three. VIKTOR BRYUKHANOV-- 50, wavy dark hair, pockmarked cheeks-- slow wakes. Fumbles for the light. Answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Hel-- His voice catches on a wad of phlegm that had settled in while he slept. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Hello? He listens for a second, then sits straight up. Behind hi in bed, his wife rolls over. Now awake. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Who else knows this? Have you called Fomin? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129 130 131 30. BRYUKHANOV (cont'd) (beat) Of course I want you to call him. If I'm up, he's up. Bryukhanov slams the phone down. Gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIKOLAI FOMIN, 50, balding, glasses, bad suit, stands waiting by the administration building. He watches as: A boxy GAZ Volga drives right up to him. Bryukhanov emerges. Also in a suit. He looks down toward the far end of the plant, past the firetrucks and flashing lights, to see where Reactor Building 4 very much on fire. And in an instant, Bryukhanov can envision a very likely fate for himself. An inquiry. An arrest. A trial. A bulle

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Whatever the cause, the important thing is neither you nor I-- Bryukhanov walks away from Fomin mid-sentence, striding toward the Administration Building. Fomin checks to see if anyone saw that small humiliation. Then hustles to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryukhanov enters, striding quickly past guards. A distan alarm sound can be heard in this simple lobby area, as we as the occasional blast of firetruck sirens from outside. He makes a sharp turn past the reception desk toward a GUARD, who is holding open a METAL DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryukhanov moves down the stairs with purpose. Fomin stil trying to keep up. They arrive at: a small, bare anteroom. In front of them, two large, STEEL BLAST DOORS - the kind you might see on bank vault.  132 133 31. A guard cranks a metal WHEEL on the left door, then PULLS THE DOOR OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryukhanov and Fomin pass through as the blast door CLANG behind them with a heavy thud. We can no longer hear the alarms or sirens. No sound from the outside world in here at all. Just the heavy CLACK of their shoes as they walk across t shiny, polished concrete floor. The bunker contains many rooms... it could almost pass fo an office center but for the too-low ceilings, exposed ductwork and repetitive, white-washed cinderblock walls. Bryukhanov and Fomin enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple room with a large oval conference table. Eightee chairs. A few phones. On the walls, maps, schematics and emergency procedure posters. Bryukhanov sees Dyatlov waiting for them in the room.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: (pissed off) I take it the safety test was a failure? Bryukhanov sits at the head of the table. Fomin takes a chair next to him-- his sidekick-- and scowls at Dyatlov.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: We have the situation under control.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Under control? It doesn't Look--

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Shut up, Fomin. (miserable) I have to tell the Central Committee about this. Do you realize that? I have to get on a phone and tell Maryin, or god forbid Frolyshev, my power plant is on fire?  32.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: No one can blame you for this, Director Bryukhanov.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Well of course no one can blame me for this. How can I be responsible? I was sleeping! Bryukhanov pulls out a pen and notepad from his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: We ran the test exactly as Chief Engineer Fomin approved. Fomin sees what Dyatlov just did there. Motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Unit Shift Chief Akimov and Engineer Toptunov encountered technical difficulties, leading to an accumulation of hydrogen in the control system tank. It regrettably ignited, damaging the plant and setting the roof on fire. Bryukhanov glances at Fomin. Does that sound right?

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: The tank is quite large. It's the only logical explanation. And of course, Deputy Chief Engineer Dyatlov was directly supervising the test-- Dyatlov registers the return fire. TouchГ©.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: --so he would know best.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: (taking notes) --hydrogen tank, fire. And the reactor?

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: We're taking measures to ensure a steady flow of water through the core.  134 33.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: What about radiation? Dyatlov hesitates for a brief moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Obviously down here it's nothing. But in the reactor building I'm being told 3.6 roentgen per hour.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: That's not great. But it's not horrifying.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Not at all. From the feedwater, I assume? Dyatlov nods.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: We'll have to limit shifts to six hours at a time. But otherwise--

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: The dosimetrists should be checking regularly. Have them use the good meter. From the safe. Dyatlov blinks at that. But otherwise... no reaction. Bryukhanov pulls a phone closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Right. I'll call Maryin. (to Fomin) Wake up the local Executive Committee. There'll be orders coming down. Bryukhanov takes a short breath... steels himself... then picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple, paved bridge passing 20 feet above the railroad lines. The CROWD we saw before-- two dozen people-- has gathered here to watch the fire. Some share vodka. Some smoke. A f of the men have their small children up on their shoulder  34. The fire occasionally shifts colors... like a rainbow. Mikhail stands with Oksana. She jiggles her pram slightly to keep her baby calm. Her four-year old son is pulling o her dress. He's tired.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: Mama-вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: Sshh. Here. She gives the boy a cracker. Then, to her husband--

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: What do you think makes the colours?

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: Oh, it's the fuel for sure.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: "Oh it's the fuel for sure"? What do you know about it? You clean floors at the train station.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: (defensive) My friend Yuri works in the plant. He says it runs cool. No fire, no gas. Just... whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: They should tell us whatever it is. Mikhail looks at her. Oh come on...

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: We live near it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: It's atoms. Yuri says the only thing is-- you can't walk right up to the fuel. But if you do-- (vodka) One glass per hour for four hours.

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: Isn't Yuri a plumber?

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: (yes, but) At the nuclear power plant.  135 35. His point well-made, Mikhail clinks his vodka cup to one his mate's. Oksana shakes her head. Boys. Then she nestles into Mikha for warmth. They all watch the fire. Calm. Peaceful, even

dialogues.speaker: OKSANA
dialogues.text: It is beautiful... The wind picks up, breezing through their hair. And with it, swirls of soot in the air, like tiny bits of paper. SLOW MOTION - as the particles swirl around them. The people stand there on the bridge, just a mile from the burning power plant, laughing, drinking... Children laugh and run in circles, trying to grab the bla snowflakes of floating soot from the air. Mikhail, watches excitedly, his baby now in his arms. The infant stares calmly at the distant light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOLYARCHUK wanders through the torn open warzone of the reactor building. Doesn't seem real. A dreamscape of billowing steam drifti across ripped metal and ruptured concrete. As the steam dissipates, he sees: A MAN, sitting on a piece of damaged equipment. All alone Breathing slowly, but heavily. Like a dying animal. Stolyarchuk walks toward him. Nervous. The man turns to him. It's YUVCHENKO-- the one who held t reactor hall door open for the trainees.

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: Do you have a cigarette? Stolyarchuk fishes a pack from his pocket, and hands Yuvchenko a cigarette. The big man reaches for it with hi left arm, as if that's the only part of his body working. Stolyarchuk lights the cigarette for him. Yuvchenko takes drag...  136 36. SPARKS sprinkle around them, illuminating the steam. It's beautiful in its own way. Yuvchenko nods with his head-- come sit with me... Stolyarchuk walks around to the right of Yuvchenko and si on the equipment next to him. And that's when he sees: BLOOD, seeping through Yuvchenko shirt in three patches: shoulder, hip, lower leg. It's wet. These aren't wounds that slowly close. These ar wounds that slowly open. Finally, Stolyarchuk finds his voice.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: Do you need help? Yuvchenko takes a drag. Savoring every moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: YUVCHENKO
dialogues.text: It's over. And now the sound of: WATER from outside, being SPRAYED b firehoses. It's penetrating the building from the floor above and begins SPRINKLING DOWN on them... like rain. Stolyarchuk raises his face to the rain. The world's gone mad. The sound of the water rises, and we're:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firefighters battle the blaze. VASILY mans a hose. He glances back at the ladder... the one Kolya went up. There's no one there. A firefighter is on all fours nearby. Vomiting. Pravik emerges from the darkness. Face darkened with soot Or something else...

dialogues.speaker: PRAVIK
dialogues.text: We've done all we can from the perimeter. We have to start making our way to the roof. Vasily glances again at the sick firefighter. Then back t the Chief. Scared.  137 138 37.

dialogues.speaker: PRAVIK
dialogues.text: There's a fire, Vasily. It has to be put out. Do you understand? Yes. The job. Vasily shuts his hose off and drags it over toward a brigade of men who are heading for the gaping HOLE in the side of the building. FROM INSIDE THE HOLE - LOOKING OUT THROUGH FLAMES - Vasil Pravik, Tishchura, and Titenok are climbing up the rubble their images distorted by the heat. They open their nozzles as they advance... From BEHIND THEM - we rise up to see: They're heading straight toward the exposed REACTOR HALL and the roaring fire belching out from the OPEN CORE... ON VASILY - gritting his teeth - the heat is tremendous.. but there's something else - a pain he shouldn't be feeling... pins and needles... And in his visor, a reflection of the fire-- --and strange BLUE FLASHES OF LIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Akimov stands by the control panel. Toptunov next to him. They're silent. REVERSE TO REVEAL: Stolyarchuk. Looking at them. Also silent. Behind him, Kirschenbaum. Everyone looks ashen. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: What about the auxiliary-- ? Stolyarchuk shakes his head. No.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: The pumps are gone. Electrical is gone.  More shocked 38.

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: The core?

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: I didn't go there. And I won't. (beat) I think it's time we faced--

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: (not interested) No. We need water in the core or there's a risk of meltdown. We have to open the valves.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: Sasha--

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: What is it you want, Boris? If it's true, then we're all dead. A million people are dead. Is that what you need to hear? silence. Then Akimov turns to Toptunov.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: We'll open the valves by hand.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: By hand? The number of valves, the amount of time to turn them-- you're talking about hours in there...!

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Then help us.

dialogues.speaker: STOLYARCHUK
dialogues.text: Help you do what? Pump water into a ditch? THERE'S NOTHING THERE. (to Toptunov) Leonid-- I'm begging you. Toptunov is terrified. But Akimov is his boss. His mentor He averts his eyes. He has no choice. Akimov gestures to Kirschenbaum.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Watch the panel while we're gone.

dialogues.speaker: KIRSCHENBAUM
dialogues.text: It's not working.  39.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Just watch it! He leaves. Toptunov doesn't look back at anyone. Just follows Akimov out. Stolyarchuk watches them go. Knows he'll never see them again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOZENS of WORKERS are assembled in a line. Shuffling into the building. SITNIKOV, 46, waits. Looks nervously at the glow of the SPOT FIRES on the roof at the other end of the plant.

dialogues.speaker: DAY SHIFT WORKER
dialogues.text: Guess we know why they called us in early.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: Is anyone saying what happened?

dialogues.speaker: DAY SHIFT WORKER
dialogues.text: They were running the safety test on the turbines and blew the control system tank. Sitnikov looks at the man. Control system tank? That?

dialogues.speaker: DAY SHIFT WORKER
dialogues.text: Doesn't make sense to me either. (quieter) What about sabotage? A bomb?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SHIFT WORKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sitnikov! Sitnikov turns to see a frantic worker running up to him.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SHIFT WORKER
dialogues.text: Bryukhanov wants us to use the good dosimeter, but it's in the safe, and we can't find the key.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: It's in Building 2. No one's-- ? Sitnikov steps out of line. Can't believe the incompetenc

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: (snaps) Follow me.  140 40. As he strides off to Building 2...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryukhanov, Fomin and Dyatlov are waiting-- then Bryukhan rises as: THE PRIPYAT COMMUNIST PARTY EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE enters. Twelve men, ages varying from 30 to 60.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, welcome. Please, find a seat, there's plenty of room-- The COMMITTEE MEMBERS take their chairs around the confer table. A guard helps an ELDERLY MAN WITH A CANE - 85 year old - over to a single, nicer chair in the corner of the

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: I apologize for the lateness of the hour. And rest assured, we're all very safe down here. We built this shelter to withstand a nuclear attack by the Americans, so I think we'll be fine. Some of the Members smile. Most do not. The Old Man in th corner has his hands folded over his cane. Eyes closed. Possibly already asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: As you can see, we have experienced an accident. A large control tank malfunctioned, damaging reactor building #4 and starting a fire. I have spoken directly to Deputy Secretary Maryin. Maryin spoke to Deputy Chief Frolyshev, Frolyshev to Central Committee member Dolghikh, and Dolghikh to General Secretary Gorbachev. An impressive murmur in the room. This is big time.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Because the Central Committee has the greatest respect for the work of the Pripyat Executive Committee, they have asked me to brief you on matters as they stand. First, the accident is well under control. Most of the Members express relief.  41.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Second, because the efforts of the Soviet nuclear industry are considered key state secrets, it is important that we ensure this incident has no adverse consequences. The Members glance at each other. Here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: To prevent a panic, the Central Committee has ordered a detachment of military police to Pripyat. And there it is. PETROV, 30, displeased, speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: PETROV
dialogues.text: How large of a detachment?

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Between two and four thousand men. Whispers. Quiet crosstalk. Four thousand? Martial law? Wh so many police?

dialogues.speaker: PETROV
dialogues.text: What's really going on here? How dangerous is this?

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: There's mild radiation, but it's limited to the plant itself.

dialogues.speaker: PETROV
dialogues.text: No it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: PETROV
dialogues.text: (stands) I said no it isn't. Who do you think you're talking to? Some country idiot? I went to university. And I have eyes in my head. (to the Committee) You saw men outside vomiting. You saw men with burns. There's more radiation than they're saying. We have wives here. We have children. I say we evacuate the town.  42. More whispers. Evacuate? To where? No, he's right-- no, he's insane, an alarmist!

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please! My wife is here. Do you think I would keep her in Pripyat if it weren't safe?

dialogues.speaker: PETROV
dialogues.text: Bryukhanov-- the fucking air is glowing! More crosstalk. Voices rising now. Bryukhanov has lost control of the room. Dyatlov tries to step in.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: The Cherenkov effect-- it's a completely normal phenomenon, it can happen with minimal radiation-- No one listens to him. Loudly arguing with each other now And then: tap tap tap ... TAP TAP TAP They turn to: THE OLD MAN in the corner. Tapping his cane on the floor. Everyone quiets down. The old man is ZHARKOV. He makes a motion to stand. The guard comes over quickly to help him up, but Zharkov wave him off. He can do it on his own. He rises slowly, then:

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: I wonder-- how many of you know the name of this place? We all call it "Chernobyl" of course, but what is its proper name? They look at each other. No clue. Until:

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: The Vladimir I. Lenin Nuclear Power Station.

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: Exactly. Vladimir I. Lenin. And how proud he would be of you tonight-- (to Petrov) --especially you, young man... and the passion you have for the people. For is that not the sole purpose of the apparatus of the State? Zharkov looks at them, his old eyes twinkling with memori of great days... of great men...  43.

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: From the Central Committee all the way down to each of us in this room-- we represent the perfect expression of the collective will of the Soviet proletariat. The Members take this in. Sobered. But proud.

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: Sometimes, we forget. Sometimes, we fall prey to fear. But our faith in Soviet socialism will always be rewarded. Always. The State tells us the situation is not dangerous. Have faith. The State tells us they do not want a panic. Listen well. Zharkov turns to Petrov once again.

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: True, when the people see police, they will be scared. But it is my experience that when the people ask questions that are not in their own best interest, they should simply be told to keep their minds on their labour-- and to leave matters of the State to the State. Zharkov scans the room. Has them in the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: We seal off the city. No one leaves. And cut the phone lines. Contain the spread of misinformation. That is how you keep the people from undermining the fruits of their own labour. That is how your names become inscribed in the hallways of the Kremlin. The men in the room look back at him in reverence. Dreami of promotions. Certificates. Maybe even medals.

dialogues.speaker: ZHARKOV
dialogues.text: Yes, comrades. We will all be rewarded for what we do here tonight. (beat) This is our moment to shine.  141 142

A beat-- then: APPLAUSE. The Committee Members rise to their feet. Wonderful! Wonderful! Bryukhanov, Fomin and Dyatlov stand and applaud as well. The system is working. All will be fine. Petrov looks across the table at another younger Committe Member. They both seem to understand that reason has lost There's no choice but to clap along with everyone else. Applause for delusion. Applause for death. Applause for the Vladimir I. Lenin Nuclear Power Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SITNIKOV listens to the applause coming from behind the door of the command room. He's sweaty. Nervous. The door to the conference room opens, and Bryukhanov see the Pripyat ministers out. Shaking their hands. Smiling. But once the ministers are out of sight, the smile drops. Back to business. He sees Sitnikov waiting. What's this g doing here? A guard whispers to Bryukhanov. Ah. Fine. Bryukhanov signals for Sitnikov to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitnikov enters. Sees Fomin and Dyatlov there.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: I sent my dosimetrists into the reactor building. The large dosimeter from the safe, the one with the thousand roentgen capac--

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: (snaps) What was the number?

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: There was none. The meter burned out the second it was turned on. Dyatlov shrugs. Suddenly calm.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Typical.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: See? This is what Moscow does. They send us shit equipment, and they wonder why things go wrong.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: We found another dosimeter. Dyatlov tenses again.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: From the military fire department. It only goes to 200 roentgen, but it's better than the small ones.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: And? Sitnikov hesitates. All his life, he's been warned not to be the bearer of bad news.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: It maxed out. Two hundred roentgen. Fomin, Bryukhanov and Dyatlov register shock. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: What game are you playing?

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: No-- I asked him, he took multiple measurements, my best man--

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: It's another faulty meter. You're wasting our time.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: I checked the meter against a control--

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you? How do you get that number from feedwater leaking from a blown tank?

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: You don't.  46.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Then what the fuck are you talking about? A long silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: I walked around the exterior of building 4. I think there's graphite. In the rubble. Bryukhanov looks at Fomin and Dyatlov, who scoff.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: You didn't see graphite.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: You didn't. YOU DIDN'T. Because it's NOT THERE. Fomin steps in. A calmer voice.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting the core-- what? Exploded?

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Sitnikov. You're a nuclear engineer. So am I. Please tell me how an RBMK reactor core "explodes". Not a meltdown-- an explosion. I'd love to know.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Are you stupid?

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Then why can't you?  47.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: I don't-- I don't see how it could explode. Fomin throws up his arms. Looks at Bryukhanov. See? Not possible.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: But it did. Dyatlov slams his fist down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: Enough! They all turn to him. Startled.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: I'll go up to the vent block roof. From there, you can look right down into Reactor Building 4. I'll see it with my own eyes. He stops. An odd look on his face. Then: He VOMITS violently. The others move back in shock. Dyatlov stares at the vomit on the floor. In a daze.

dialogues.speaker: DYATLOV
dialogues.text: I apologize. He tries to lean on the table for support, but misses completely and COLLAPSES to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Guards! Three guards run in.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Take him to the medic. Or the hospital. Whatever he needs. Two of the guards lift Dyatlov off the floor. Begin helpi him walk out. Dyatlov has a strange look on his face. We've seen it before. Right after the explosion. Bewildered.  48.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: (to Bryukhanov) It's the feedwater. He's been around it all night. Bryukhanov nods. Then Fomin glances at Sitnikov.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: You go then.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Go to the vent block roof and report back what you see.

dialogues.speaker: SITNIKOV
dialogues.text: No. No, I won't do that. Fomin and Bryukhanov stare at him. Did he just say "no"?

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Of course you will. Bryukhanov looks to the remaining guard. Gives him a "mak sure he does it" nod. Sitnikov turns pale. No way out of this.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: You'll be fine. You'll see... No he won't. Sitnikov turns, looks at the guard... then walks out. Like a man going to the gallows. The guard follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AKIMOV and TOPTUNOV, sloshing through water and debris up to their knees. They stop and see: REVEAL - STANDPIPES - dozens of them in a convoluted arra with more VALVES than we could ever count.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's begin. He moves ahead. Toptunov doesn't.  144 49.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: Leonid. Toptunov nods. Right. He joins Akimov at the standpipes. Each takes a valve. Begins turning. The valves are TIGHT. They're straining to make them move at all.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: All the way, okay? All the way open. No sound but that awful, distant hissing, and the sharp metal squeal of the valves. Then:

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AKIMOV
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be sorry for. I told you-- we did nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: TOPTUNOV
dialogues.text: But we did. Akimov stops turning his valve. Doesn't answer. Doesn't look at Toptunov. Just stands quietly for a second. Then puts his hands back on the valve and resumes turning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metal utility door opens. Sitnikov steps out on to the tar paper and gravel roof. Takes a few steps, then looks back at: THE GUARD - who waits back - no expression. Just a blank face and an AK-47 slung by a strap over his shoulder. Sitnikov turns away - looks out at the sky. The horizon i just starting to lighten. From up here, he can see the flashing of emergency vehicl below. And ahead of him: THE EDGE OF THE ROOF - and beyond it, coming up from underneath... SMOKE and the glow of FLAMES. Beyond the edge of that roof is the viewpoint down into Reactor Building 4.  145 50. And either it is or is not open to the air. And either he is or is not about to die. He looks at his watch. 6 AM. He starts walking. Slowly. Forcing each step. The crunch his shoes in gravel. The feeling of his heart in his ches THE EDGE - looms closer Fifteen feet away. Ten feet. Five feet. He stops. Closes his eyes. A prayer-- or a memory-- or a goodbye. Then he opens his eyes, and-- BEHIND SITNIKOV - we watch as he walks to the edge. He looks over. Just for a second. Then lifts his head, turns, and starts walking back. The guard is watching. Sitnikov has begun to cry. And the sound of the world fades away...

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION 145
dialogues.text: DYATLOV is helped out of the building, stumbling, his arm around an emergency worker. He looks and sees: Firefighters on the ground. Their friends screaming for help. A female SECURITY GUARD is on her hands and knees. Dazed. Blood streaming from her nose. The left side of he face is red and blistered. Dyatlov sees VASILY and Titenok carrying Pravik on a stretcher. But Vasily passes out and FALLS... vomiting... Pravik is dumped to the ground... crying out in pain... Dyatlov looks out toward the damaged end of the plant, th cascade of rubble... It doesn't make sense. What happened?  146 51. SITNIKOV, nuclear tan on his face from that brief moment exposure, sits in the bunker command room. Bryukhanov and Fomin are yelling at him. Threatening him. Gesturing in disbelief and contempt. Sitnikov isn't listening. Doesn't care if they believe hi or not. He's thinking about what he's lost. Who he's lost ZINCHENKO, the young doctor, is ASLEEP in a small exam ro by the reception lobby. Nurses are RUNNING in the hallway in the foreground. Zinchenko wakens, and walks out into the lobby-- toward t main entrance-- and sees through the open doors: FLASHING LIGHTS - ambulances and fire engines streaming toward the hospital. More than she ever wanted to see heading her way... And now, the sound of: A PHONE RINGING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat lifts its head. Awakened by the sound. LEGASOV wakes up. It's two years before we first met him, but he looks much younger. Full head of hair. More weight in his face. Healthy color. He gets out of bed, crosses out of his room, makes his wa into the kitchen, and answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Valery Legasov?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: You are the Legasov who is the First Deputy Director of the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy? Legasov feels his pajama shirt pocket for his glasses. Bu left them back in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes. That's--  52. He picks up the table clock to get it closer to his eyes. It's 7:00.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Who am I spea-- ?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is Boris Shcherbina, Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers and head of the Bureau for Fuel and Energy. There's been an accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant. Legasov is immediately alert.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: No need to panic. There was a fire. It's mostly put out. The system control tank exploded.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Control system tank. Is the core-- ?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: We've ordered them to continuously pump water.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I see. And contamination?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mild. The plant manager, Bryukhanov, is reporting 3.6 roentgen per hour.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Well, no, that's-- that's actually quite significant. The surrounding areas should be evacuated--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: (cuts him off) You're an expert on RBMK reactors, correct?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes, I've studied--  147 148 53.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: General Secretary Gorbachev has appointed a committee to manage the accident. You're on it. We'll convene at two this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (concerned) That late? I'm sorry, but I think given the radiation you're reporting, it might be best to--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Legasov. You're on this committee to answer direct questions about the function of an RBMK reactor if they should happen to arise. Nothing else. Certainly not policy. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. I didn't mean to-- Click. Shcherbina has hung up. Legasov hangs up as well a rises. Gears already spinning. 3.6 roentgen... ? A strang number. The control system tank? It makes no sense. He moves to his window. Opens the curtains to the SUNRISE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SUN, brightening to a glare. BOOM DOWN to find: The torn-open reactor building, even more horrifying in t daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move low and slow through a strange MIST - water vapou hovering thick - flooding and debris have almost turned t facility into a swamp... We turn a corner and as the mist dissipates, we see: AKIMOV AND TOPTUNOV, still by the valves. Both weak from radiation sickness. Faces swelling. Hands trembling and reddened.  149 54. They've been here for hours. Each of them barely consciou Hardly enough strength to turn the valves. But still, they try. We FOLLOW the maze of standpipes, bending around and climbing up damaged concrete walls until at last: THE END of the pipes. Torn open. Water gurgling out of them in small spurts. Not cooling a reactor core. Not doing anything at all. Just puddling into broken concrete, and then spilling dow a METAL DRAIN GRATE.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS 149
dialogues.text: The roof fires are out. But the fire within the core rage unseen. Smoke plumes out, moving in the wind... OVER THE FOREST BETWEEN THE REACTOR AND PRIPYAT - we can see the path the deadly wind has been taking, because a wide swath of the trees have turned a terrible RUST ORANG color. THE HOSPITAL, surrounded by a parking lot of emergency vehicles... THE STREETS, as concerned shopkeepers open up for the day business. We see MILITARY VEHICLES passing by in the B.G. And a line of CHILDREN, 7-years old, in their uniforms an book bags, holding hands and laughing as they walk to school. Move in and low to the ground now... until we're just looking at the children's shoes as they pass by. A moment or two, and they're out of frame. Then a BIRD drops to the ground in front of us, hitting t cement with a sickening sound. It twitches for a moment, then goes utterly still.
